utterances: Well, they're, look, they're very committed.
It's guerilla warfare, which takes a very long time.
They're a number of actors from outside Iraq who have interest in keeping this going.
They've got a lot of resources, which we sometimes don't, you know, just along those lines.
One thing that makes this war unique, these people have no shortage of weapons and high explosive.
In most insurgencies, just getting adequate supplies of high explosive and weapons is a real challenge.
In Iraq because of the truly staggering amounts of weapons and high explosive that were left scattered around by the Saddam Hussein regime, that's not a problem for them.
Hmm.
That already is a huge difference, I think, from other insurgencies.
David, thanks for the call.
Thank you.
One final question for you, Eliot Cohen.
Another of the mistakes you said the United States made in Iraq, post-war Iraq, or I guess, post- the fall of Baghdad, was a lack of unity of command.
Right, you know, I think a lot of the debate about what some of the mistakes that were made in Iraq followed a red herring, which is the numbers issue.
That was important, how many troops.
But I think the history of insurgencies tells us that organization, doctrine zone matter a lot more.
And of the things that matters most is to have the military and civilian functions completely integrated.
Do you have, the people who are in charge of security also worrying about development, and the supply of clean water and electricity, and all the rest?
Thank you.

Our most successful commanders over there, for example, General Peter Corelli, who's now the Corps Commander there, as a divisional commander, he said, you know, what's gonna be important for ensuring stability in Baghdad is, do these people have sewage?
Do they have water?
Do they have electricity?
And he made that happen, and incidents in his sector went way down.
On a much larger scale, it was a terrible decision to have military leadership on the one hand and then the Coalition Provisional Authority under Ambassador Bremer.
And eventually you had two competing hostile bureaucracies which were not very cooperative.
And insurgency, above all kinds of war, is one where the political, the economic, the social has to be completely interlinked and interwoven with the military.
And you only get that if you have one person in charge, the military or civilian.
Eliot Cohen, thanks very much for being with us today.
Thank you very much.
Eliot Cohen, Professor of Strategic Studies at the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University.
The book we were talking about is Military Misfortunes: The Anatomy of Failure in War.
I'm Neal Conan.
This is Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington, sitting in for Neal Conan.
Yesterday the last soldier left.
Three weeks ago, the last settlers left.
For the first time in 38 years, Israel is out of Gaza.
Israel still controls its borders and checkpoints as well as water and electricity, but Palestinians are now closer to holding their fate in their own hands.
The world will be watching closely in coming weeks and months to see how the Palestinians deal with this new freedom and with whatever assets the Israelis left behind.
Can they quell the violence, overcome corruption and rebuild an economy that has literally been reduced to rubble?
We'll go to Israel for the latest news, talk with a settler who left and analyze what the future may hold for Gaza and Israel.
Do you have questions about the new relationship between the Palestinians and Israelis?
How has it changed?
How is it the same?
Join the conversation.
Our number here in Washington is (800) 989-8255.
That's (800) 989-TALK.
And our e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
Later in the program, we'll review highlights from today's Senate confirmation hearings for chief justice of the United States.
But first, life after the Gaza pullout.
Joining us now is Carol Hezi, a settler who used to live in the Gadid settlement in Gaza.
She joins us by phone from her hotel near Jerusalem.
Hi.
Thanks for being with us, Carol.
You're welcome.
Now I know you talked with the program a few weeks ago soon after leaving Gaza.
You are still living in a hotel.
Are you any closer to getting permanent housing at this point?
It's being built.
They're starting to build it--put it that way.
Nothing's on the ground yet, but the papers have been signed.
Now I know that you and your neighbors from Gadid were hoping to stay together as something of a community.
Is that what you're still working on?
Are you going to be able to do that?
We're still--yes, that's the plan.
Maybe you could explain what it is you're planning to do.
What is it you're building?
The government is building temporary housing, temporary meaning for two or three years.
They're sort of prefabricated--what they call caravans.
They're like mobile homes, but they're not on wheels.
Right.
And you'll be in some kind of a community with the people that you lived nearby in the settlement.
And we'll be about half of the people who were living in Gadid.
Yeah.
Have your feelings at all changed in these few weeks about disengagement?
Or what are your feelings now?
Nothing now.
No, nothing's changed.
We had to sit yesterday and watch, or choose not to watch the Palestinians looting and burning and destroying the synagogues that were left.
Did you watch?
No.
No, I refused to watch.
Did other people around you watch?
Was your husband watching, or...
No.
No, most everybody I knew either wouldn't turn on the television at all or turned it right off.
It's too hard to watch that.
Yeah.
What are conditions like where you're living now?
As far as hotels go, it's quite nice, but it's very hard to live in a hotel for more than a few days.
Yeah.
And then what do you envision for the future?
What--this place--you're going to be in mobile homes as temporary housing.
I mean, what--do you see the future for yourself at this point really?
It's not something particularly to look forward to.
A mobile home is much smaller than, of course, the houses that we had and not as weather-proof.
It's not really something to look forward to, but it's going to have to suffice for two or three years until the ground can be prepared for building something more permanent.
I understand you'd want to be in a religious community.
Is that right, and if so, why is that?
Because that's what we were used to.
Uh-huh.
Why is that important?
It builds up the community.
We built up a community in the sense of people are like almost family.
So you don't want to go and just, you know, start your life over among a bunch of strangers.
Right.
How about your children?
What's happening for your children right now?
And suddenly at the last minute, though, the government voted to keep the former synagogue building standing.
Now the Torah scrolls and everything of religious value have been taken out of these buildings...
There are high expectations for the incoming president.

His election on November 4 was a historic moment in American history that triggered celebrations in the streets and jubilant exclamations of ""Only in America."" But for black America, November 4 also triggered a lot of soul searching.
To talk about that, we've invited author and political analyst Jonetta Rose Barras and Chicago Tribune columnist Clarence Page into our Washington studio.
Welcome to both of you.
Clarence, it's nice to see you again.
Thank you, Liane.
Thank you.
It's good to be here.
Jonetta, I want to start with you.

You wrote an op-ed piece in The Washington Post about race relations in America, and you described the election of Barack Obama as the beginning of a - and I'll put this in quotation marks - ""post-racial America."" What do you mean by that?

Well, I think that we have actually been coming to this place incrementally, I would say, since the 1990s, when you saw a new generation of young people who had actually come of age in an integrated America.
And while they appreciated the history of their parents and their grandparents, they certainly were not burdened by it, were not imprisoned by all of the racial stuff that many of us went through.
So now we see that these young people, and some older people too, are interacting in a way that is not burdened by the past.
I think that we will see more and more of this kind of interaction at a real genuine human level, and not a level that is colored by class and race.
Clarence, I wanted to hear what you had to say.
Do you agree with it?
